Cedric Beust wrote:

>>This is a 
>>reasonable thing to do, but it's not something that JUnit really lends
> 
> itself to.
> 
> Really?  I was thinking that suite() would let you do that pretty easily.
> 


There are various ways you could do it. My concern is that however you 
do it:

1. You may well need to print out more details than can easily fit in an 
assert failure message in order to reproduce the problem.

2. You should probably statically generate the test cases once before 
the test suite is run rather than every time the test suite is run.

JUnit is designed to run repeatedly. It is designed to let you know when 
you broke something that was working before. Anything beyond that and 
you'll find yourself working against the API rather than with it. That's 
fine, of course. One tool does not fit all needs. What makes JUnit a 
good tool for unit testing makes it inappropriate for algorithmically 
generating test data.

One particular code smell I encounter frequently is when JUnit suites 
have lots (or any) System.out.println() statements. That normally 
indicates someone is trying to get more data out of JUnit tests than 
they're really intended to produce. It's even worse if these statements 
print when the tests are passing as well as failing. In this case, 
actual failures are likely to get swamped by the usual output and may 
well not be noticed, especially when running from Ant or the 
textui.TestRunner so there's no red bar. Honestly I think the standard 
Ant JUnit task produces too much output already. I only want to see 
tests that failed. I want line of output at most if all tests passed.
